The oceans.

 
There is only one place where the beauty of the Earth could be almost completely observed, the Space. But, you don't have to travel into space to realize how much water is on our planet.
 
About 70% of the earthly surface is made up of sea oceans, being home to a large number of living beings, however, thanks to its vastness it is known that there is greater knowledge about other places in space than the world that exists within our oceans.
 
We all know how salty the seas and oceans of our planet are, but not many know why. The reason oceans are so salty is due to various processes that occurred throughout Earth's history, such as the erosion of rocks, the evaporation of water or the formation of sea ice, which over time have altered the chemical properties of the ocean, making it salty.
 
An interesting effect is what causes the solar radiation that reaches our planet, because the way it reaches different parts of the terraqueo balloon causes a difference in temperatures between the water at the poles, which is colder and the water at the equator which is the hottest on the planet.
 
This imbalance of temperatures is the one that gives impetus to atmospheric and oceanic circulation, although forces such as wind, tides and Earth's rotation also influence ocean circulation.



Importance and changes of oceans.



The ocean on earth is a huge source of resources for humans, from marine food and medicine to energy source probe or storm protection, for this reason it is necessary to keep in mind its value and take into account that in the absence of oceans, our planet would be completely uninhabitable.
 
However, for many years the planet has gradually increased its temperature, this at the root of the warming that has manifested itself and accelerating since the 1970s.
 
The oceans have absorbed a lot of this heat and as a result, great changes have been observed that harm life on the planet; a decrease of some marine species such as phytoplankton has been observed, in addition to the melting of the ice from the poles that has increased rapidly over the past decades. According to the satellite observations of the current ones, a decrease in the area of the poles covered by sea ice has been found.
 
CURIOUS FACT: phytoplankton is the basis of the aquatic food chain and its behavior is like that of terrestrial plants; it feeds on carbon dioxide producing by means of photosynthesis, oxygen. This oxygen is part of half the oxygen we breathe daily.
 
Thanks to these remote sensing satellites, specialized scientists have the opportunity to study the characteristics of the ocean as well as its changes in order to predict the impact of environmental changes on the ocean in the future and improve life within the planet.
 
NASA, as an example, has observed terrestrial oceans from space for more than 38 years, beginning with the launch of the first civil oceanographic satellite, SEASAT, on January 28, 1978.
 
Today there are a lot of aerial and satellite missions observing the ocean, measuring a lot of parameters such as: topography of the ocean surface, currents, waves, phytoplankton content, expanse of seafarer's ice, salinity of the sea surface, among others. NASA in conjunction with partners has worked on several of these missions.
